multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the shape of this graph in the context of the article?
choices: It demonstrates that the inequality (7) holds for all values within the region 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.
The graph illustrates the relationship between x, y, and z for a fixed value of p.
The shape of the graph proves that the inequality (4) holds for all values of a, b, and c.
It helps to demonstrate that the inequality (7) holds even at the critical points, aiding in the proof of Theorem 2.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the intersection of the two curves in this figure important?
choices: The intersection points represent the solutions to equation (9), which are crucial for determining the critical points in the proof of Theorem 2.
The graph highlights the difference in behavior between the functions u and 1 + (u/2)<sup>(1/p)</sup>.
This figure illustrates the convexity of the function u → 1 + (u/2)<sup>(1/p)</sup>.
It shows that the equation u = 1 + (u/2)<sup>(1/p)</sup> has no solutions for u < 2.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of plotting this function in relation to Lemma 8?
choices: The graph visually confirms that the inequality in Lemma 8 holds for all 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.
It demonstrates that the function (x<sup>p</sup> + 4x<sup>(p/2)</sup> + 1) / (1 + x)<sup>p</sup> has a minimum at x = 0.5.
By analyzing the graph, particularly near x = 0 and x = 1, the authors gain insight into proving the inequality stated in Lemma 8.
This figure shows that the function (x<sup>p</sup> + 4x<sup>(p/2)</sup> + 1) / (1 + x)<sup>p</sup> is always positive.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key property of the function represented in this graph is used in the proof of Lemma 8?
choices: The graph shows that the function is always positive for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.
It highlights that the function has a maximum value at x = 0.5.
The concavity of the function, as demonstrated by the shape of the graph, plays a crucial role in proving Lemma 8.
The graph indicates that the function is symmetric around x = 0.5.
